Brooklyn (3).name: Grave of DeWitt Clinton
Brooklyn (3).description: The Father of the Erie Canal has a magnificent grave marker that redefines the term "final resting place."

Brooklyn (3).name: Tomb of Secrets on Bay Grove Hill
Brooklyn (3).description: A way to take your secrets to someone else's grave.

Brooklyn (3).name: The Brooklyn Clay Retort and Fire Brick Works Storehouse
Brooklyn (3).description:
The factory that helped produce a dominant form of lighting before Thomas Edison.

The three-kiln factory, which began producing clay retorts and fire bricks in 1859, continued production until the early 1930s. It was later bought and restored by Greg O’Connell, a Red Hook developer. The space now houses the Carvart Glass Company, which creates architectural glass products for noteworthy New York City buildings.

Brooklyn (3).name: Sunny's
Brooklyn (3).description: Once a popular watering hole among longshoremen and shipyard workers, this neighborhood treasure spans more than 100 years of Red Hook history.

Brooklyn (3).name: Dream Fishing Tackle
Brooklyn (3).description: As the name suggests, Dream Fishing Tackle was a place for anglers to buy new rods and bait when Robert Piskorsa opened the Greenpoint shop in 1994. And while the original awning remains the same, over the past three decades Piskorsa’s daughter Barbara has transformed the inside into an overflowing (some admirers say “overwhelming”) supply of Art Deco and postmodern furniture — along with plenty of records, vintage posters, and chandeliers, too.

Brooklyn (3).name: Kato Sake Works
Brooklyn (3).description: Their Bushwick tasting room / bottle shop has vinyl nights and live music multiple nights a week, food pop-ups and more.

Brooklyn (3).name: Allison Eden Studios
Brooklyn (3).description: Allison Eden Studios is a custom glass art house for all mosaic tile. This one- of-a-kind art studio, which has been manufacturing creative custom tile in NYC for over 30 years, makes some of the most intricate and beautiful tile and mosaic art on the market. The studio also serves as a kind of glass mosaic museum featuring the pop art culture of the city’s past and present.

Brooklyn (3).name: Carroll Hall
Brooklyn (3).description:
Carroll Hall is a hidden botanical walled garden and series of buildings that explore material reuse of the site and ideas of time travel and ecology to create immersive, unlikely experiences. Visitors continually discover the unexpected within an architecture of crafted materials and unconventional construction techniques. The buildings breathe with automated windows and skylights to naturally ventilate. Handmade mosaic murals tell stories of underground creatures. There are moving walls and secret doors. The plants are an idealized woodland, dressed-up cousins of what might have grown along the edges of fields and farms past.

The wall that contains the garden is an artwork constructed of pieces from previous buildings on site—from 16,000 years ago to today. It is a time machine. Designers reused over 11,000 salvaged bricks from the demolition of an existing warehouse to create a 200-foot long streetwall of reassembled bricks and stones, illustrating the material history of the site in an impressionistic tapestry.

Brooklyn (3).name: Noble Signs Inc
Brooklyn (3).description: New York Sign Museum

Brooklyn (3).name: Balcones Recycling
Brooklyn (3).description: offers tours once a month

Brooklyn (3).name: Environmental Study Center
Brooklyn (3).description: This 7,000-square-foot learning center in Bergen Beach, Brooklyn, is home to over 200 living organisms, four learning labs, an outdoor learning space with a pond habitat and urban garden, and a greenhouse laboratory

Brooklyn (3).name: NOoSPHERE Arts
Brooklyn (3).description: a new cultural center in the heart of the industrial zone of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, that focuses on the intersection of art and ecology. Their mission is to produce and share experimental arts programming because NOoSPHERE believes art has the power to move people where lectures fall short. With a hub of talent that unites music, dance, visual arts, theater, film, poetry, and prose, their collaborative productions foster connections between migrant artists and locals.

Brooklyn (3).name: L10 Arts & Cultural Center
Brooklyn (3).description: The newly-opened 65,000 square-foot space is a giant facility that houses space for multiple institutions: three new cinemas for BAM, the Brooklyn Public Library’s first branch dedicated to arts and culture, a gallery, café, and performance space for the Museum of Contemporary African Diasporan Arts (MoCADA), and lastly, 651 ARTS‘ first performance space.

Bucharest.name: Palace of the Deposits and Consignments
Palace of Parliament
Bucharest.description: This communist behemoth is the heaviest building in the world and a legacy of a brutal regime.

Bucharest.name: Cărturești Carusel
Bucharest.description: This once-derelict building is now one of the most beautiful bookstores in the world.

Bucharest.name: Revolution Square
Bucharest.description:
Although a rather ordinary looking plaza, the historical significance of Revolution Square makes it one of the important places to go to understand the events of Romanian Revolution of 1989.

It was here in December of 1989 that dictator Nicolae Ceausescu gave his last speech to an unexpectedly (to him, at least) angry crowd. After the speech, he and his wife fled by helicopter, but were quickly captured, tried and executed on Christmas Day. The events ended a 42-year reign of Communism in Romania.

Standing in the center of Revolution Square is the 82-foot-tall Memorial of Rebirth. Although the design is disliked by many locals in Bucharest (they call it “The Potato on a Stick”), it honors the 1,500 lives lost in the Romanian Revolution and the rebirth of the nation.

Bucharest.name: Snagov Monastery
Bucharest.description: This solitary monastery may hold the remains of Vlad the Impaler (but probably not).

Bucharest.name: Arcul de Triumf
Bucharest.description: Romania's triumphal arch looks out over Bucharest.

Bucharest.name: Memorial of Rebirth
Bucharest.description: This memorial to the victims of the Romanian Revolution of 1989 is often compared to a potato on a skewer.

Bucharest.name: Curtea Veche Palace
Bucharest.description: The bust of Romania’s most notorious ruler, Vlad Dracula aka "Vlad the Impaler," keeps watch over the ruins of his medieval court.

Bucharest.name: Biserica Zlătari
Bucharest.description: The preserved arm of a third-century sorcerer is believed to have the power to lift curses and spells.

Bucharest.name: Professor Engineer Dimitrie Leonida Technical Museum
Bucharest.description: Check out engineering marvels of the past at this unintentionally retrofuturist museum.

Bucharest.name: Monument to the Heroes of the Air
Bucharest.description: This sculpture used famed boxer Joe Louis as the inspiration behind its body.

Bucharest.name: Politehnica
Bucharest.description: This metro station doubles as an unintentional paleontology museum.

Bucharest.name: The Ruins of the Chiajna Monastery
Bucharest.description: Locals believe this abandoned ruin on the outskirts of Bucharest is haunted.

Bucharest.name: The House of Ceaușescu
Bucharest.description: The kitsch mansion of the former Romanian president Nicolae Ceaușescu features a golden bathroom.

Bucharest.name: "Văcărești" Nature Park
Bucharest.description: After sitting unused for decades, this abandoned communist infrastructure became a wildlife utopia.

Bucharest.name: Palatul Mogoșoaia
Bucharest.description: 17th century palace once a meeting place for politicians.

Bucharest.name: "The Little Paris" Museum
Bucharest.description: This museum offers a journey back to the Belle Epoque era of Romania.

Bucharest.name: "Saint Anthony" Church
Bucharest.description: Also known as Biserica Curtea Veche – or Old Court Church – Biserica Sfantul Anton stands as the oldest church in Bucharest. Built in the mid-1500s, the structure features a patterned red-and-white brick exterior. Still used regularly by locals – especially on Tuesdays, when women go to pray for health, wealth or for finding a husband – it is also one of the top Old Town Bucharest tourist attractions.

Bucharest.name: Biserica Doamnei
Bucharest.description:
During Communism, many historic churches in Bucharest were either demolished, moved or hidden from sight by apartment blocks. Bucharest visitors can seek out some of the hidden churches in and around the Old Town today.

Doamnei Church is hidden in the old city center and one of the Bucharest must-see sights. Wedged behind a block of flats, the Doamnei Church dates to the late 1600s, and has suffered damage due to multiple earthquakes throughout the centuries. The church stands as a Romanian Ministry of Culture Historic Monument.

Bucharest.name: "Kretzulescu" Church
Bucharest.description: Built in the 1720s in the Romanian Brancovenesc style, the small red-brick Kretzulescu Church is one of the top Bucharest places to visit. Saved from demolition during the Communist era, the church features original mural paintings on the porch. The frescoes inside, however, were painted in the mid-1800s by painter Gheorghe Tattarescu

Bucharest.name: Catedrala Mantuirii Neamului
Bucharest.description: When finished, it will rank as the tallest and largest Eastern Orthodox Church (by volume and area) in the world.

Bucharest.name: Antim Monastery
Bucharest.description: A beautiful and serene monastery amongst the hustle and bustle, Antim Monastery is one of the peaceful and relaxing places to visit in Bucharest. Built in 1715, the Antim Monastery is accessed by walking through a tunnel under a bell tower. The church itself features an ornately carved wooden door and interior paintings that date to the early 1800s. There is also a small museum on site.

Bucharest.name: The Patriarchal Cathedral
Bucharest.description:
Sitting atop the small Dealul Mitropoliei Hill, the Romanian Orthodox Patriarchal Cathedral is a top Bucharest landmark. Officially named the Patriarchal Cathedral of Saints Constantine and Helena, it is the center of the Romanian Orthodox Church.

Step inside to see the ornate iconostasis, stained-glass windows and colorful frescoes. Surrounding the church are grand buildings, including a museum and the Patriarchal Palace. Visitors can also take in the sweeping views of Bucharest and the People’s Palace from a small viewpoint near the small shop on the north side of the cathedral.

Bucharest.name: Radu Vodă Monastery
Bucharest.description: Radu Voda Monastery is a 16th century monastery tucked into a quiet neighborhood. While it feels a bit off the beaten track, it is busy with people who come to pray. Inside, visitors will find a glittering iconostasis, ancient relics and the founder’s tomb. Additionally, the grounds provide a sheltered oasis where you can take a rest.

Bucharest.name: "Carol I" Park
Bucharest.description:
Designed as a French garden in 1900 and used for the 1906 Bucharest Exhibition, Park Carol I is one of the interesting places to see in Bucharest. The park features shaded paths, panoramic views, heaps of monuments and a couple museums. The most striking (and contentious) monument is the Nation’s Heroes Memorial and Mausoleum.

Built in the 1960s to honor socialist militants and as a place of burial for leaders, the monument took on new meaning after the fall of Communism in Romania. Renamed the Nation’s Heroes Memorial, the mausoleum now hosts the remains of Romanian soldiers and a flame burns for the Unknown Soldier. Unfortunately, it is impossible to get close to the monument or visit the mausoleum; it’s guarded and entering any area of the memorial is strictly prohibited.

Bucharest.name: The House of the Free Press
Bucharest.description:
Once reigning as the tallest building in the city (from 1956 until 2007), the House of the Free Press is still an impressive Bucharest landmark. The Stalinist style building was constructed to house Romania’s printing presses and news staff. Many Romanian newspapers are still headquartered inside the building today.

A statue of Stalin once stood in front of the massive structure. Today, the winged Aripi Monument – another tribute to Romanians who lost their lives fighting Communism – stands in its place.

For visitors, taking in the grand view of the Free Press Building from the monument is one of the interesting things to do in Bucharest – especially for fans of Socialist Modern architecture.

Bucharest.name: "Cotroceni" National Museum
Bucharest.description:
One of the more unusual things to do in Bucharest is to go to the Romanian president’s house, Cotroceni Palace. Although tours are limited to the part of the house that is designated as the National Museum, it’s still worth the effort to see the interior.

To tour the impressive palace, guests are required to make reservations in advance. In fact, to even step foot on the grounds, a reservation and passport are required (so keep that in mind before trekking out to see it!).

Bucharest.name: Ferestroika
Bucharest.description: The small, 3-room apartment is a time capsule that captures everyday life in Bucharest in the 1980s. Museum guests are invited to interact with the exhibits…as if visiting a friend’s house.

Bucharest.name: George Enescu National Museum
Bucharest.description: Located inside the extravagant Cantacuzino Palace, the George Enescu National Museum is one of the best places to visit in Bucharest to learn about the famous composer. Exhibits feature artifacts and memorabilia dedicated to George Enescu and his music.

Bucharest.name: Cartierul Armenesc
Bucharest.description: armenian quarter

Budapest.name: Metropolitan Ervin Szabó Library
Budapest.description: A 19th-century artistocrat's mansion, turned into a library, hidden in a modern library. While it can be a confusing process to find the Central Library in the maze-like modern section of the library, once you do, all that is left is to pick out a beautiful old book, sink back into a deep leather chair, surrounded by the soft light of chandeliers, and relax like a 19th-century Hungarian aristocrat.

Budapest.name: Vajdahunyad Castle
Budapest.description: This Hungarian castle was built out of cardboard and wood until it proved so popular that it got upgraded to stone. Also hosts the Budapest Agricultural Museum where a  fake Transylvanian castle houses a cathedral of antlers.

Budapest.name: Museum of Applied Arts
Budapest.description: tWHS - Ödön Lechner's independent pre-modern architecture

Budapest.name: Szent László Church
Budapest.description: tWHS - Ödön Lechner's independent pre-modern architecture

Budapest.name: Buda Castle Funicular
Budapest.description: Built in 1870 at the bridge that connected Buda and Pest, this spectacular incline railway was almost lost forever during World War II.

Budapest.name: Andrássy út
Budapest.description: WHS

Budapest.name: Molnár János Cave
Budapest.description: tWHS - Caves of the Buda Thermal Karst System

Budapest.name: Palvolgyi Cave
Budapest.description: tWHS - Caves of the Buda Thermal Karst System

Budapest.name: Szemlő Mountain Cave
Budapest.description: tWHS - Caves of the Buda Thermal Karst System

Budapest.name: Ferenc-hegyi Cave
Budapest.description: tWHS - Caves of the Buda Thermal Karst System

Budapest.name: Mátyás-hegyi barlang
Budapest.description: tWHS - Caves of the Buda Thermal Karst System

Budapest.name: József-hegyi Cave
Budapest.description: tWHS - Caves of the Buda Thermal Karst System

Budapest.name: Buda Castle
Budapest.description: WHS

Budapest.name: Hungarian Parliament Building
Budapest.description: WHS

Budapest.name: Thermae Maiores
Budapest.description: Legions of Roman soldiers bathed in this ancient spa complex under a Budapest transit station.

Budapest.name: Ministry of Agriculture
Budapest.description: bullet holes in arcade

Budapest.name: Zugliget Chairlift
Budapest.description: A two-way chairlift system between Zugliget and the highest point in the city.

Budapest.name: Mansfeld Peter Memorial
Budapest.description: This statue of a falling man commemorates a teenage martyr of the Hungarian Revolution.

Budapest.name: Hospital in the Rock
Budapest.description: A museum dedicated to a secret military hospital hidden beneath a castle in Budapest.

Budapest.name: Szimpla Kert
Budapest.description: A Trabant car, a kangaroo statue, and a plethora of plants take over this abandoned-factory-turned-bar.

Budapest.name: Memento Park
Budapest.description: Budapest's Communist-era statues, banished to the suburbs.

Budapest.name: Semmelweis Museum
Budapest.description: A museum in the childhood house of a medical pioneer.

Budapest.name: Epreskert
Budapest.description: The romantic garden was the epicenter of the Hungarian art scene in the 1880s.

Budapest.name: Zwack Unicum Museum
Budapest.description: Central Europe's largest collection of mini-bottles is on display at this museum devoted to a bitter Hungarian liquor.

Budapest.name: Hungarian Electrotechnical Museum
Budapest.description: Electrical curiosity museum housed in an old transformer station.

Budapest.name: Michael Jackson Memorial Tree
Budapest.description: A random tree outside a Budapest hotel has become a DIY shrine to the late singer.

Budapest.name: Párisi Udvar
Budapest.description:
a fine example of
Eclectic architecture popular in the
late 19th century and drawing on a
multitude of earlier styles. Originally
part of a bank building, the arcade has
recently been restored.

Budapest.name: St. Stephen's Basilica
Budapest.description: home to the Holy Right - The mummified right fist of a 1,000-year-old saint-king sits inside an ornate golden reliquary.

Budapest.name: Rosenstein Vendéglő
Budapest.description: Dine on Hungarian-Jewish dishes at this multigenerational, family-run institution

Budapest.name: Urania National Film Theater
Budapest.description: A stunning Art Nouveau cinema in the heart of Budapest.

Budapest.name: Ghetto Memorial Wall
Budapest.description: The holes in this wall provide a glimpse into Jewish life in Budapest, both past and present.

Budapest.name: Carl Lutz Memorial
Budapest.description: This sculpture honors the man who was known as the "Righteous Among the Nations."

Budapest.name: Memorial for Victims of the German Occupation
Budapest.description: A highly-criticized monument in Budapest has become the site of a makeshift Holocaust memorial.

Budapest.name: Statue of Imre Nagy
Budapest.description: A much-loved sculpture depicting the hero of a 1956 anti-Soviet uprising

Budapest.name: The Policeman
Budapest.description: Also known as Uncle Karl, the beloved bronze copper keeps a watchful eye on St. Stephen’s Basilica while people rub his lucky belly.

Budapest.name: Gömböc-szobor
Budapest.description: The largest statue of this convex, homogeneous object with just one stable and one unstable equilibrium point.

Budapest.name: For Sale Pub
Budapest.description: This Budapest bar allows drinkers to leave their mark on the walls, floor, and even ceiling.

Budapest.name: Centrál Grand Cafe & Bar
Budapest.description: Some of the greatest minds in the history of Hungarian art and science converged in this café.

Budapest.name: Shoes on the Danube Bank
Budapest.description: A trail of iron footwear stands as a monument to the thousands executed along this riverbank during WWII.

Budapest.name: Citadella-kilátópont
Budapest.description: From Austrians to Nazis to Soviets, this historic Budapest fortress has a history as complex as the city itself.

Budapest.name: Gellért Hill Cave
Budapest.description: Once the home of a hermetic monk, this cave now houses a small church.

Budapest.name: Hűvösvölgy, Children's Railway
Budapest.description: This quaint Hungarian railway system is operated exclusively by children between the ages of 10 and 14.

Budapest.name: Garden of Philosophers
Budapest.description: Tucked away near more famous landmarks lies a statue meant to symbolize the confluence and continuing development of human culture. In a secret corner of Budapest's Gellért Hill, the world's greatest religious figures meet silently around an orb. At least, that's what Hungarian sculptor Nándor Wagner envisioned when he created "The Garden of Philosophy," a cluster of statues you may happen upon if you wander away from the major tourist attractions of the Citadel and the Liberty Statue, perched atop the crown of the popular hill overlooking the Danube.

Budapest.name: Mining and Geological Survey of Hungary
Budapest.description: This hidden art nouveau gem was designed by an architect in search of a national style.

Budapest.name: Postal Savings Bank
Budapest.description: tWHS - Ödön Lechner's independent pre-modern architecture

Budapest.name: The Church of Our Lady of Buda Castle
Budapest.description: The towers of Matthias Church stand as integral landmarks within the Castle District. Yet many locals and tourists alike have never ventured inside the building (see recent photos here). The church, in line with tradition, was consecrated by order of St Stephen, though its construction took place during the reign of Béla IV in the 13th century. Despite undergoing reconstruction, renovations, and damage by the war, the church endures, though only fragments of its original features remain. The building exudes a uniquely special and almost mystical atmosphere, with its walls adorned with rich decorations. The tower offers one of the most stunning views of the city, provided you're willing to climb the 200 steps up to the top.

Budapest.name: MOL Campus
Budapest.description: Controversial and divisive, the MOL Campus, Budapest’s first skyscraper, has introduced a new colour and style to the city at the end of 2022. This architectural addition has reshaped the city's skyline while pushing the boundaries in terms of technical innovation. In April, its lookout point also opened, allowing visitors to take in panoramic views from a height of 120 meters. Anticipate unconventional yet breathtaking vistas, which are worth a visit whether you find the building itself captivating or polarizing. While the visitor's centre can be entered free of charge, a ticket is required to access the SkyDeck terrace

Budapest.name: Vigadó Concert Hall
Budapest.description: Built in 1865 based on the plans of Frigyes Feszl, the Vigadó is perhaps the last reminder of the pre-World War II ambience of the Danube Promenade. The famous Danube-side hotels burned for three days after the bombing of the city during World War II, and the Vigadó was severely damaged. It was only restored decades later, in the 1980s. As well as the exciting programmes, social events, and the beauty of the building, it is worth taking in the spectacular views from the windows and roof terrace. It's easy to sneak into the building for exhibitions and programmes, but it's worth a stroll to discover its secrets.

Center (Brasov).name: Strada Sforii
Center (Brasov).description: This snug medieval lane is one of the narrowest streets in the world

Center (Brasov).name: The Black Church
Center (Brasov).description: A fire once nearly devoured this gorgeous 14th-century Gothic cathedral.

Connecticut.name: Palisado Cemetery
Connecticut.description: THE HEADSTONE OF EPHRAIM HUIT is inscribed with the year 1644. It is not the oldest grave or the first burial in the country, but it is the oldest surviving headstone in Connecticut and believed to be the oldest legible, dated headstone in the United States.

Connecticut.name: Vintage Radio & Communications Museum of CT
Connecticut.description: More than a century of radio history is told in these displays. Listen to pop music from throughout the 20th century on a variety of jukeboxes, put on a set of vintage headphones and tune into live radio broadcasts on a period crystal radio, and dial up friends and family using rotary phones and in phone booths. All that and more is ready to be experienced at this museum dedicated to educating the public about the history of electronic communications and the state’s contributions. Proceeding chronologically from the 1850s through the 1970s, the museum chronicles the rise of radio and evolution of communications through a collection of radios, typewriters and industrial equipment, phonographs, televisions, TV studio equipment, telephones, recording studio equipment, and even the first computers. Also explore the rivalries between communications pioneers Thomas Edison and Alexander Graham Bell and, later, Edison and George Westinghouse and Nikola Tesla, by trying out Edison’s early lightbulb designs and a miniature version of Tesla’s renowned coil.

Connecticut.name: Matianuck Natural Area Preserve
Connecticut.description: Sand dunes from a glacial lake are preserved in this woodland park.

Connecticut.name: State House Square
Connecticut.description: site of Isle of Safety : The former location of a platform that allowed passengers to safely wait for the trolley.

Connecticut.name: Connecticut's Old State House
Connecticut.description:
A wunderkammer hidden on the top floor of the Hartford statehouse. 
"The place where Connecticut’s democracy was born has seen more than its fair share of hard times. Nearly demolished at least twice in the 20th century, including in the 1970s when it almost faced the wrecking ball to make way for a parking lot, the National Historic Landmark built in 1796 closed last summer due to budget cuts. But the Old State House, which was Connecticut’s original seat of government from 1796 to 1878, is once again open to the public. Stroll through the chambers of the House of Representatives and the Senate, where the Amistad trial began and the 13th Amendment was ratified, and spy an original portrait of George Washington. Resist the urge to take a spin on Mark Twain’s bicycle. Things get a little wacky when you venture upstairs into the Museum of Natural and Other Curiosities, where the walls are lined with rare masks, animal heads and bizarre items such as a “unicorn’s horn” and a two-headed calf."

Connecticut.name: Ancient Burial Ground
Connecticut.description: The oldest place in Hartford is a cemetery with thousands of bodies stacked beneath the grass.

Connecticut.name: Horace Wells Statue
Connecticut.description: The tragic tale of the dentist who pioneered the use of anesthesia.

Connecticut.name: Statue of Rover
Connecticut.description:
A tribute to the truly loyal dog who waited outside a hospital for his owner to come back.
When facing the front entrance to the main Hartford Hospital go to the left side of the entrance. The statue is close to the wall near the windows.

Connecticut.name: Cathedral of Saint Joseph
Connecticut.description: This Connecticut chapel is a starkly modern, and surprisingly colorful, architectural rebel. "The original cathedral, with its classical twin Gothic spires, was destroyed by a New Year’s Eve fire in 1956. The church that replaced it — a 281-foot concrete and limestone edifice with straight lines and hard edges — would have been unrecognizable to those familiar with the original. But inside is where the beauty truly lies. Even for the non-religious, being surrounded by vividly colored stained-glass friezes towering more than six stories, the sun coursing through, it’s difficult not to feel the influence of a higher power. Look up at a ceiling full of stars. And look forward to the altar, behind which is one of the largest ceramic tile murals in the world"

Connecticut.name: A. Everett Austin House
Connecticut.description: This stunning Connecticut mansion is actually just a one-room-deep hoax.

Connecticut.name: Connecticut Museum of Culture and History
Chapel by the sea
Connecticut.description: How did the right arm of a 13th-century English bishop wind up in a Connecticut church?

Connecticut.name: Mystic Seaport Museum
Connecticut.description: Holding multiple historical boats and an entire 19th century village, this New England attraction is the largest maritime museum in the world.

Connecticut.name: Gungywamp
Connecticut.description: The kind of mixed-up place that drives archaeologists crazy.

Connecticut.name: Submarine Force Library & Museum
Connecticut.description: The US Navy's only submarine museum is also home to the world's first nuclear submarine.

Connecticut.name: Seaside Sanatorium
Connecticut.description: Ruins of a historic medical facility sits eerily by the water.

Connecticut.name: The Book Barn
Connecticut.description: With some 500,000 books across five buildings, this bookstore is a reader's paradise.

Connecticut.name: SoNo Switch Tower Museum
Connecticut.description: Back in the olden days, railroad traffic was controlled by a tower containing an interlocking machine with a series of mechanical levers. The SoNo Switch Tower was one of them, constructed in 1896 by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad to control switches at the junction between the New Haven Line and the Danbury Branch to move trains from one track to another, which was done by railroad employees. Open weekends, the tower features the state’s only “Armstrong” switch lever machine, so named because you needed to have a strong arm to operate it. Test your strength by throwing the levers, just as the tower operators did for nearly a century.

Connecticut.name: Well’s Dinosaur Haven
Connecticut.description: A free display of artistic lifesize dinosaur sculptures in a backyard garden.

Connecticut.name: American Clock & Watch Museum
Connecticut.description: Thousands of American timepieces on display in the former clock-making capital of the country.

Connecticut.name: The Carousel Museum
Connecticut.description: A parade of antique steeds offers a quirky ride through history.

Connecticut.name: Witch's Dungeon Classic Movie Museum
Connecticut.description: A seasonal movie monster museum featuring wax creations by a relative of one of the original Universal Studios monsters.

Connecticut.name: Shade Swamp
Connecticut.description: An abandoned Depression-era zoo hidden just off the highway.

Connecticut.name: PEZ Visitor Center
Connecticut.description: The world's largest public collection of PEZ memorabilia.

Connecticut.name: Hill-Stead Museum
Connecticut.description: NHL

Connecticut.name: William Kent Charitable Foundation
Connecticut.description: The farmhouse where a reclusive sculptor and printmaker created thousands of works.

Connecticut.name: Warehouse Point Library
Connecticut.description: A replica of fossils believed to be the first scientifically-described dinosaur bones found in North America.

Connecticut.name: Silver Sands State Park
Connecticut.description: This park is home to a massive bird sanctuary. 2.6-mile stroll on a magical ocean walkway that opens up twice daily (and also disappears twice daily).this hike is closed during the summer

Connecticut.name: Charles Island
Connecticut.description: This "thrice-cursed" island is allegedly home to Captain Kidd's lost treasure. You are not allowed on the Island from May-August due to endangered bird nesting.

Connecticut.name: Connecticut Trolley Museum
Connecticut.description: A preserved trolley track that was transformed into a museum of transportation.

Connecticut.name: Cogswell Memorial Fountain
Connecticut.description: Dr. Henry Cogswell hoped that his elaborate drinking fountains would dissuade people from drinking alcohol.

Connecticut.name: John Oliver "Balls of Steel" Memorial
Connecticut.description: After the comedian dissed a Connecticut town on his show, they named a sewage treatment plant after him.

Connecticut.name: HADDAM SHAD MUSEUM
Connecticut.description: Springtime is go time for this repurposed shack and the fish it venerates.

Connecticut.name: Machimoodus State Park
Connecticut.description: The Connecticut village named for its subterranean thunder.

Connecticut.name: Boothe Memorial Park
Connecticut.description: This eclectic homestead is home to a miniature windmill and Connecticut's last tollbooth.

Connecticut.name: Biology Physics Building
Connecticut.description: A giant ant model welcomes visitors to an exhibit about symbiotic organisms that live with army ant colonies.

Connecticut.name: EEB Biodiversity Education & Research Greenhouses
Connecticut.description: An artificial tree in the University of Connecticut greenhouses holds a collection of orchids, mosses, and other tropical epiphytic plants.

Connecticut.name: Ballard Institute and Museum of Puppetry
Connecticut.description: Celebrating an art form with a collection of puppets from all over the world.

Connecticut.name: Thread City Crossing
Connecticut.description: Public outcry led to this bridge's unique character which celebrates a giant frog battle and also sewing.

Connecticut.name: Best Video Film & Cultural Center
Connecticut.description: This Connecticut video store has a vast and varied archive that contains everything from 'Koyaanisqatsi' to 'The King's Speech.'

Connecticut.name: Pirelli Building
Connecticut.description: After decades of neglect, a brutalist icon is getting new life as an eco-friendly hotel.

Connecticut.name: Meriden Traffic Control Tower
Connecticut.description: A human attendant once directed car traffic from this structure before automated stoplights.

Connecticut.name: Ingalls Ice Rink
Connecticut.description: It looks like a whale, it's part of Yale, and it's best-known by a nickname you can probably work out for yourself.

Connecticut.name: The American Museum of Tort Law
Connecticut.description: It was founded by Ralph Nader to educate the public about an often-maligned area of law.

Connecticut.name: Connecticut Air & Space Center
Connecticut.description:
A humble air museum located in an original World War II aircraft factory. 
"oused within a former aerospace factory and across the street from Igor I. Sikorsky Memorial Airport, the Connecticut Air & Space Center has the feel of a top-secret site. The property is owned by the federal government. As a result, people under age 18 are not permitted on the site, and all visitors must stop by a security building at 550 Main St. around the corner from the museum, for a quick safety briefing before being allowed access (don’t worry, it’s safe!). Once they get “clearance,” guests are rewarded with an engrossing immersion in Connecticut’s rich aerospace history: Igor Sikorsky developed the helicopter across the street, Charles Lindbergh kept his plane nearby for a time, a line of flying saucer-like planes were briefly planned in Stratford. And, of course, Gustave Whitehead — at least according to any aviation historians in Connecticut worth their salt — beat the Wright brothers to the air. This history comes alive thanks to the showstopping restorations of many historic aircraft featured at the center. Last May, the center held a groundbreaking ceremony for the first phase of restoration on the historic Curtiss Hangar, across the street from the center."

Connecticut.name: Davison Art Center, Wesleyan University
Connecticut.description: NHL This distinctive house was built in the late 1830s in a transitional Greek-Italianate style. It now belongs to Wesleyan University.

Connecticut.name: The Institute Library
Connecticut.description: One of America's oldest private membership libraries was long one of New Haven's best kept secrets.

Connecticut.name: Woolsey Hall
Connecticut.description: Taft Chair: An extra-wide chair built to accommodate the former president's big behind.

Connecticut.name: Connecticut River Museum
Connecticut.description: This museum holds a fully-functional replica of the "Turtle," the first American submarine ever built. Dedicated to New England’s great river, the museum is housed in an 1878 Steamboat Dock building and along its surrounding docks. Guests can take an “art walk” and trace the river’s 410-mile course from northern New Hampshire to Long Island Sound; climb aboard a replica of the Turtle, the world’s first submarine used during the American Revolution; learn about the 1814 British raid on Essex; follow the historic evolution of steamboats and wooden ships; and even explore the river by sail by booking an afternoon or sunset cruise on the schooner Mary "E, from June through October"

Connecticut.name: Heublein Tower
Connecticut.description: This lovely hilltop tower was specifically built to withstand 100 MPH winds.

Connecticut.name: Dividend Pond And Ruins
Connecticut.description: Now home to hardy plants, these sand and gravel dunes once held back a massive prehistoric lake.

Connecticut.name: Nathan Hale Schoolhouse East Haddam
Connecticut.description: One of America's first spies started out as a teacher in this little red one-room schoolhouse.

Connecticut.name: Curioporium
Connecticut.description: A journey through a curious collection of oddities and wonder.

Connecticut.name: Tidal Marsh Trail
Connecticut.description: A once-booming railroad left abandoned next to the Quinnipiac River marshes now intersects with a hiking trail.  The entrance to the hiking path is behind the Target and easy to find with signs in the area for the Tidal Marsh Trail.

Connecticut.name: Goodspeed Opera House
Connecticut.description: This opera house along the banks of the Connecticut River has two Tony Awards to its credit but it’s never staged a single opera.

Connecticut.name: Essex Steam Train & Riverboat
Connecticut.description: This classic steam-powered train takes tourists on a nostalgic trip around the Connecticut River Valley.

Connecticut.name: Sleeping Giant Observation Tower
Connecticut.description: Amazing views of Long Island Sound can be seen from this mountaintop tower.

Connecticut.name: Remington Shot Tower
Connecticut.description: Connecticut's shot tower is near the end of its life.

Connecticut.name: Lock 12
Connecticut.description: This historic park site contains the last remnants of a once bustling canal system.

Connecticut.name: Exley Science Center
Connecticut.description: A small museum packed with specimens from important fossil sites and minerals from historical pegmatite quarries. TUCKED AWAY ON THE FOURTH floor of the Exley Science Center at Wesleyan University, the Joe Webb Peoples Museum is a showcase of geological and natural wonders. Though not much bigger than a large living room, the museum houses enough material for a space 10 times its size.

Connecticut.name: Danbury Railway Museum
Connecticut.description: This historic railway museum may have lost its passengers but not its love for trains.

Connecticut.name: The Griswold Inn
Connecticut.description: British troops and Prohibition couldn’t stop this spot from becoming one of the United States' oldest continuously-run taverns.

Connecticut.name: Mine Hill Preserve
Connecticut.description: The remnants of a 19th-century ironmaking complex hidden in the woods of Connecticut.

Connecticut.name: Harvey Cushing/John Hay Whitney Medical Library at Yale
Connecticut.description: A vast collection of rare books, manuscripts & extraordinary objects illustrating the history of medicine.

Connecticut.name: Barker Character Comic and Cartoon Museum
Connecticut.description: A museum dedicated to antique toys, collectibles, and nostalgia.

Connecticut.name: Judges Cave
Connecticut.description:
The cave where two British judges hid in exile after sentencing the king to death. 
"New Haveners will recognize the names Whalley, Dixwell and Goffe for three major roadways in the city. What Elm City residents and others in the state might not know is the incredible story behind the three names, a story that connects New Haven to what, at the time, were earth-shaking political developments. In 1649, during the English Civil War, some 59 British judges signed a writ of execution for Charles I (“regicide”), and three of them — Edward Whalley, John Dixwell and William Goffe — fled for the colonies. The three judges hid out on the top of West Rock in what is now called Judges Cave, a rock formation situated along the south end of Regicides Trail, a 7-mile, blue-blazed hiking trail. The cave is still there, with a plaque that tells the story with the quote: “Opposition to tyrants is obedience to God.”"

Connecticut.name: Yale Collection of Musical Instruments
Connecticut.description: A quirky assortment of musical marvels from around the world.

Connecticut.name: Castle Craig
Connecticut.description: A lone tower rises above the cliffs in a city park, offering fantastic views of the Connecticut landscape.

Connecticut.name: Iglesia Ni Cristo - Johnsonville Extension
Connecticut.description: This picturesque Victorian ghost town was once a thriving mill community.  Currently, Iglesia ni Cristo does not allow anyone on the property without permission. Since the village is on a public road, taking photos from the road should not be a problem.

Connecticut.name: Abbey of Regina Laudis
Connecticut.description: These Benedictine nuns have been making artisanal cheeses since before it was cool.

Connecticut.name: Hogpen Hill Farms
Connecticut.description: A famed data visualizer's personal sculpture garden is a landscape of modern and megalithic wonders.

Connecticut.name: The Glass House, National Trust for Historic Preservation
Connecticut.description: Home of Philip Johnson, one of the 20th century's most influential architects.

Connecticut.name: Hearthstone Castle
Connecticut.description: A castle inspired by medieval architecture is hidden in the woods of Connecticut.

Connecticut.name: East Rock Park
Connecticut.description: Panoramic views of the city of New Haven and the Long Island Sound, with a side of history.

Connecticut.name: Supercharged Indoor Karting and Axe Throwing
Connecticut.description: The world's largest indoor go-kart racetrack is hiding in Connecticut.

Connecticut.name: Old New-Gate Prison & Copper Mine - Seasonal
Connecticut.description: A former copper mine which became a truly unsuccessful prison.

Connecticut.name: Center Church On The Green
Connecticut.description: 137 graves holding New England's earliest residents.

Connecticut.name: The Barnum Museum
Connecticut.description: A museum designed by and dedicated to P.T. Barnum in the town where he is buried.

Connecticut.name: Dinosaur State Park
Connecticut.description: The ancient past meets the retro-future at these dinosaur tracks that are protected by a geodesic dome.

Connecticut.name: Gay City State Park
Connecticut.description: The ruins of an abandoned 18th-century town that is slowly being reclaimed by the forest.

Connecticut.name: Gillette Castle State Park
Connecticut.description: Quirky castle designed by the American actor best known for portraying Sherlock Holmes on stage.

Connecticut.name: The Cushing Center
Connecticut.description: An archival collection of over 2,200 case studies which includes human brain specimens and tumor specimens.

Connecticut.name: Abandoned Fairy Village
Connecticut.description:
A miniature village lies nearly forgotten in the forest by the side of a major highway.
This location does not have an address and is both very easy to get to and mildly difficult to access if you are driving there in a car. The closest place to park is Maggie McFly’s (a restaurant). To access the fairy village, find Old Waterbury Road. At the end of this road is an old access road that is now more of an overgrown trail. You cannot drive down the access road, and there are signs saying you cannot park on Old Waterbury Road or risk being towed. They don’t want people parking there to walk to the village.

While not restricted or illegal, the town doesn’t make it easy to access the area because they are worried about vandalism and misuse. You will need to walk along the service road until you see giant power lines and the highway in front of you. Once you pass under the giant power lines keep to the left going into the woods down a well-walked trail. Depending on the time of year the path is usually pretty visible. Go towards the crumbling main large human-sized hut. On the other side, you will find the cliff throne and some of the best-preserved fairy houses. There are several houses in various states of crumbling ruin scattered throughout the forest, but be careful if you stray from the trails; there is a lot of poison ivy.

Connecticut.name: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library
Connecticut.description: Yale University's home for rare works, including the mysterious Voynich Manuscript.

Connecticut.name: Holy Land USA Waterbury
Connecticut.description: A religious-themed park filled with folk art to bring biblical stories to life that fell into disrepair and now being restored.

Connecticut.name: Pinchot Sycamore Tree Park
Connecticut.description: largest tree in CT

Connecticut.name: CT Audubon Birdcraft Museum
Connecticut.description: NHL - Oldest bird sanctuary in the U.S., where Mabel Osgood Wright originated "birdscaping".

Connecticut.name: Roseland Cottage
Connecticut.description: NHL Gothic revival summer cottage visited by three U.S. presidents. Take a peek into the life of 19th-century business titan Henry Bowen and his family, who sought refuge from the heat and tumult of New York City. The 1846 Gothic Revival cottage with its lush Victorian interiors is best known for its delightful architecture and having a pink exterior — and it features the oldest surviving indoor bowling alley in the U.S.

Connecticut.name: New England Air Museum
Connecticut.description: Next to Bradley International Airport, the New England Air Museum is home to more than 100 vintage aircraft displayed in three large hangars, from early flying machines and biplanes to helicopters, fighter jets, and a B-29A Superfortress bomber. There are flight simulators and special open cockpit days when visitors can sit in the cockpit of selected aircraft. The collection extends to engines, instruments, aircraft parts, uniforms and personal memorabilia

Connecticut.name: Pine Knob Loop Trail Trailhead Parking
First Presbyterian Church
Connecticut.description: NHL - a major Modernist church design

Connecticut.name: Fort Shantok Archeological District
Connecticut.description: NHL - Mohegan settlement and home of the seventeenth century sachem Uncas.

Connecticut.name: Florence Griswold Museum
Connecticut.description: NHL - Boarding house frequented by American impressionist artists such as Henry Ward Ranger, Childe Hassam, and Willard Metcalf.

Connecticut.name: Slater Memorial Museum
Connecticut.description: The plaster cast collection is the crown jewel of the Slater Memorial Museum on the campus of Norwich Free Academy. In 1887, a fellow named Edward Robinson, head of the classical collection at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, was tapped to select sculptures to be duplicated and installed at the museum — works like the Nike of Samothrace on display at the Louvre in Paris. The Slater’s plaster cast replicas cover thousands of years of Assyrian, Egyptian, Greek, Roman and Renaissance sculptures. Paintings and artifacts from Europe are also on display, and there’s a Gallery of African Art as well.

Connecticut.name: Windham Textile & History Museum (the Mill Museum)
Connecticut.description: There’s so much to see at the Mill Museum in the former headquarters of the American Thread Co. There’s a historical society, library and archive, in addition to the museum, which preserves and interprets the history of textiles and the textile industry in Connecticut. Visitors can take in the Mill Workers’ House, Mill Manager’s Mansion, Brooke Shannon Antique Sewing Machine Room, and Peggy Church Weaving Studio, among others. And look for the special exhibit Here All Along: African Americans in Northeastern Connecticut Before the Great Migration, which explores the African American experience in northeastern Connecticut from the 1600s to 1910.

Connecticut.name: Connecticut Antique Machinery Museum
Connecticut.description: A page has been added to the CAMA website describing its newest addition — the new wing of the Connecticut Museum of Mining and Mineral Science. Called the Hall of Connecticut Geology and Paleontology, the exhibits explore the creation of the patch of earth called Connecticut, and all the upheavals that created the geology we see in the state today. The paleontology of Connecticut is another focus, though the core attraction is antique machinery and plenty of it, including industrial technology, internal combustion engines, steam engines, and machinery designed for agriculture and logging.

Connecticut.name: Bush-Holley House
Connecticut.description: The Greenwich Historical Society is home to an intriguing house museum with a dual identity; one side embodies the site’s Colonial and post-Colonial past, while the other shows off its identity as the centerpiece of the Cos Cob art colony and a bastion of American Impressionism. The most famous guest was Childe Hassam, who painted Bowl of Goldfish at the site.

Connecticut.name: American Radio Relay League
Connecticut.description: Come visit ARRL! The main adminstrative building includes a well-appointed reception area with exhibits and a membership store. Outside, visitors can navigate a self-guided tour that includes the ARRL Diamond Terrace composed of inscribed bricks placed by committed ARRL Diamond Club members, other monuments, the historic Maxim Memorial Station, W1AW, and its present-day antenna farm. For any additional questions please contact Jon Faasen, AA1EZ: 860-594-0387

Connecticut.name: Enders State Forest
Connecticut.description: short hike to Enders Falls - some consider best waterfalls in the state

Connecticut.name: Mattatuck Museum
Connecticut.description: home to the waterbury button museum

Connecticut.name: Saville Dam
Connecticut.description: "Completed in 1940 and located on the eastern branch of the Farmington River, the dam creates the 8-mile-long Barkhamsted Reservoir, which serves as the primary water source for Hartford. This is a place where you come to get away and to enjoy the quiet and the stunning views. You might even spy a soaring bald eagle. (It’s a favorite haunt of many photographers.) There are also some pleasant walking trails in the area. But if you’re planning a long stay, make sure to bring food and drinks; there are no dining options in the immediate vicinity."

Connecticut.name: The Shore Line Trolley Museum
Connecticut.description: Presenting the story of the trolley and other mass transit in a historical context, the Shoreline Trolley Museum operates the Branford Electric Railway, opened in 1900 and recognized as the oldest continuously operated suburban trolley line in the U.S. Collections include equipment, photographs, documents and artifacts, but the fun part is the ride that takes visitors past the shoreline salt marsh. During the trip, the trolley operator discusses the restored trolleys in the collection and explains how they helped shape transportation. There are also lots of fun seasonal events.

Connecticut.name: The Institute For American Indian Studies
Connecticut.description: Tucked away on 15 wooded acres, the Institute for American Indian Studies has a 16th-century Algonquian village, a fun Wigwam Escape adventure, and a museum with displays of artifacts from prehistory to the present that inform and enhance visitors’ understanding of the history and culture of Native Americans, whose story is honored and recounted through a combination of archaeology, research, exhibitions and programs.

Connecticut.name: Haystack Mountain Tower Parking And Trailhead
Cathedral Pines
Connecticut.description: one of last remaining old growth forests in region

Connecticut.name: Fort Trumbull State Park and Museum
Cedar Swamp
Connecticut.description: NNL

Connecticut.name: Putnam Memorial State Park
Connecticut.description: "Billed as “Connecticut’s Valley Forge,” Putnam Memorial State Park is the oldest state park in Connecticut. It is located on the site of the winter encampment of Gen. Israel Putnam’s Continental troops, who stayed on the grounds from December 1778 to May 1779. Guests can learn more about this Revolutionary history and the site’s archaeological surveys at the visitor center, museum and reconstructed camp buildings or by following in the footsteps of those who fought to form this country, on an interpretive trail."

Connecticut.name: Stewart B. McKinney National Wildlife Refuge
Denison Pequotsepos Nature Center
Connecticut.description: offers tours to gungywamp

Connecticut.name: Enders Island
Connecticut.description: pretty little island; used as a cathoilic retreat; in chapel, there's the arm of St Edmund

Connecticut.name: Pachaug State Forest
Connecticut.description: the Great Meadow Swamp section is a NNL

Connecticut.name: Blue Slope Country Museum
Connecticut.description: This appointment-only museum connects the land with the story of how our agricultural history played a vital role in the rural development of New England through the display of agricultural-history artifacts from the 17th through 20th centuries, including farming tools and implements, household objects, and carpentry tools. Altogether there are 4,000 artifacts in the collection. Seasonal events include square dances in the barn and tractor-driven wagon rides for the holidays.

Connecticut.name: Fort Griswold Battlefield State Park
Connecticut.description: "If you need another reason to hate Benedict Arnold, a visit here will do it. In 1781, Arnold, an American general who famously switched to the British side, led a raid on New London and Groton that resulted in the massacre of more than 80 troops at this fort across the Thames River in Groton. There is a memorial to these fallen soldiers, and guests can wander at will through the remains of the structure, which is among the best examples of a Revolutionary War fort still in existence. The Ebenezer Avery House, which sheltered the wounded after the battle, is also on the grounds. The site is part of the Thames River Heritage Park, which connects the fort with City Pier in New London and Fort Trumbull across the river by means of a water ferry running seasonally Friday, Saturday and Sunday."

Connecticut.name: Sculpture Walk
Connecticut.description: look for sculpture that commemorates the first instance of an American president pardoning a turkey.

Connecticut.name: 120 Huyshope Ave
Connecticut.description: future site of Coltsville NHP

Connecticut.name: Connecticut Valley Hospital
Connecticut.description: cemetery - not sure exactly where it is "A truly hidden Connecticut experience, the challenging and even emotionally difficult graveyard at Connecticut Valley Hospital offers a window into the troubled history of how the mentally ill were treated in Connecticut. Located at the edge of the hospital grounds, the cemetery is the final resting place of some nearly 1,700 people, buried there in numbered, unnamed graves from 1878 to 1955. In 1999, local clergy worked with the hospital and the state to get the names of those buried in the plot recovered and inscribed on a monument which now stands on Silvermine Road. The numbered graves are not easy to look at, but the cemetery is a story of lives and dignity — lost and then recovered."

Connecticut.name: Bigelow Hollow State Park
Connecticut.description: "This jewel of our park system, way up in the northeast corner and “hidden” away in the 9,000-acre Nipmuck State Forest, has a lot to keep you occupied. This time of year, you might still have some time for cross-country skiing and snowmobiling. But we think it’s during the warmer months that this park truly shines. Miles of hiking trails will keep your activity tracker on overdrive. Boating and fishing are a blast in the Mashapaug Pond, which is actually a 300-acre lake that touches the Massachusetts state line. This is one of the great places to be in the state for fall foliage, as the densely packed trees offer a fiery canvas, while the lake waters provide a beautiful mirrored surface. But also be mindful of the wondrous array of wildlife, including the occasional bobcat, moose and bear."

Connecticut.name: McLean Game Refuge
Connecticut.description: NNL

Connecticut.name: Nike Missile Site HA-36 control site
Connecticut.description: inside a state forest, the forgotten remains of a Cold War defensive installation.

Connecticut.name: Buttonwood Farm Ice Cream
Connecticut.description: only really go when the sunflowers are in bloom

Connecticut.name: Aerosol Techniques Factory
Connecticut.description: This enormous abandoned factory is now a makeshift graffiti gallery.

Connecticut.name: Bradley Mountain Farm
Connecticut.description: full moon goat hikes

Connecticut.name: Cunningham Tower
Connecticut.description: Hidden among the trees of Goshen’s Mohawk State Forest sits a little piece of history. After driving – or walking – up the winding roads of Mohawk Mountain, there’s a little trail that leads to a 20-foot tall tower. Cunningham Tower, built in 1912, was first purchased for sheep farming. Now, its inside only includes a picnic table and stone fireplace.

Connecticut.name: Bulls Covered Bridge
Connecticut.description: Take a look back in time while walking under the single-lane vehicular wooden covered bridge in Kent. While the current Bulls Bridge was constructed in 1842 from timber, the first instance of a bridge at the location over the Housatonic River was built back in 1760. It’s only one of three surviving covered bridges in the state.

Connecticut.name: High Rollers Luxury Lanes & Sports Lounge
The Brewery at Maple View Farm
Bunker Hill Trailhead Parking
Connecticut.description: Lions Head Trail - Short-and-sweet 2.1-mile hike to an awesome rocky outcropping with an even more awesome view

Connecticut.name: MoCA CT
Connecticut.description: Devoted to contemporary art, MoCA showcases an impressive mix of local and international artists, all in the service of building a deeper understanding of creative expression. A permanent exhibition by the late Westport artist Ann Weiner, When Caged Birds Sing, features eight life-size sculptures representing current women’s rights activists

Connecticut.name: Eric Sloane Museum
Connecticut.description: This museum covers a lot of ground, as it’s devoted to an artist, author and illustrator of books who also assembled an extensive collection of hand tools and Americana. The tools are displayed in a building given to the state in 1969 by Stanley Works. Sloane’s studio tells the story of his career as an artist, during which he painted landscapes inspired by the Hudson River School, and later, New England culture and Colonial life. Examples of his art are displayed in the adjacent gallery. Sloane built a pioneer cabin next to the museum, and the Kent Iron Furnace, which operated from 1826 into the 1890s, is also on the property.

Connecticut.name: Housatonic Museum of Art
Connecticut.description: Located at Housatonic Community College, this museum, spanning the history of art and on continuous display in the 300,000-square-foot building, contains works by big names such as Christo, David Hare, Leonard Baskin, Wayne Thiebaud, Ernest Briggs, Anne Arnold, Theodore Robinson, Cleve Gray, Jeff Koons, Cindy Sherman and Jenny Holzer, among others. The collection also includes African and Native American arts and artifacts.

Connecticut.name: William Benton Museum of Art
Connecticut.description: Connecticut’s official state art museum, the William Benton Museum of Art on the UConn Storrs campus has been renovated and expanded since its days as a modest operation located in a historic dining hall called The Beanery.

Connecticut.name: Tapping Reeve House and Law School
Connecticut.description: Two vice presidents, 28 U.S. senators, 101 members of the House, six cabinet members, and three U.S. Supreme Court justices were among the leaders educated at the nation’s first law school in Litchfield, opened by lawyer and judge Tapping Reeve in 1784. Visitors experience the 19th-century life of legal students, as well as students of the Litchfield Female Academy, through role-playing, hands-on areas, and interpretive exhibits. The Tapping Reeve Meadow out back, with its arbors and Adirondack chairs, is a haven where the Scarecrows in the Meadow display each fall is a smash hit.

Connecticut.name: Museum of Connecticut History
Connecticut.description: Exhibits focus on the state’s government, military and industrial history, its growth and its role in the development of the nation from the Colonial era to the present. But don’t think the museum is boring. The Colt’s Patent Firearms Manufacturing Co. collection includes the original Rampant Colt statue that sat atop the Hartford Colt factory, as well as a Colt-made Gatling gun. Fun fact: The museum has more than 50 vintage Connecticut-made toasters in its collection.

Connecticut.name: New England Civil War Museum
Connecticut.description: Housed within an original Grand Army of the Republic meeting hall — it’s the country’s oldest continuously run GAR hall — the museum has one-of-a-kind artifacts including weapons, personal items and memorabilia from the Civil War, with an emphasis on Connecticut’s contributions. With hundreds of books and periodicals in its library, the museum, founded in 1896 but not officially opened to the public as a museum until 1994, is a prime spot for research related to the Civil War and the Union Army.

Connecticut.name: Ruby & Calvin Fletcher African American History Museum
Connecticut.description: The artifacts of oppression on display here can be shocking to see in person. But they also inform, reflecting the African American experience in the U.S. from slavery and the Civil War through the civil rights movement. The “up close and personal” viewpoint of the relatively new museum (it opened in 2021) stresses teachings of tolerance, diversity, unity and educating people that there was a time when imagery played a significant role in how African Americans were perceived.

Connecticut.name: Prudence Crandall Museum
Connecticut.description: Connecticut’s official heroine isn’t a household name, but Prudence Crandall became a pioneering equal rights champion beginning in 1832 when she was the principal of the Canterbury Female Boarding School and agreed to a request from Sarah Harris, a young Black woman, to attend the school. Residents protested, Crandall closed the school but reopened the following year to serve non-white students. Things then got worse for Crandall, but litigation that resulted influenced two major U.S. Supreme Court decisions. Visitors can see period rooms, rotating exhibits, a small research library, and a new gift shop opening this season.

Connecticut.name: Custom House Maritime Museum - New London Maritime Society
Connecticut.description: Located in the historic customs house designed by noted architect Robert Mills (also responsible for the Washington Monument) and built in 1833, the Custom House Maritime Museum tells the stories of New London’s waterfront and seafaring history through exhibits, lighthouse tours, boat trips, an annual chowder festival, and displays of artifacts related to the local lighthouses and the Amistad. All of it is overseen by the New London Maritime Society. To this day, a working customs office still conducts its work here, the oldest continuously operating one in the country.

Connecticut.name: The Genius Museum at Nature's Art Village
Connecticut.description: Technology and progress are the focus at the Genius Museum at Nature’s Art Village, where guests learn how newspapers were printed in the 19th century and how a steam engine powers a boat, for example. Don’t miss the Steam Engine Room, where there’s a 2 p.m. engine startup on Saturdays and Sundays. Other exhibits include Hayday Farm, the Montville Queen steamboat, and the Oakdale Country Store.

Connecticut.name: National Helicopter Museum Inc
Connecticut.description: Located in the eastbound railroad station in Stratford, the National Helicopter Museum features a photo essay about helicopter development, a chronicle of helicopter pioneers, including Igor Sikorsky, multiple helicopter models, a T53 gas turbine engine developed in Stratford, and a computer flight simulator. The centerpiece of the museum is a full-size cockpit you can pop into.

Connecticut.name: Connecticut Eastern Railroad Museum
Connecticut.description: The Connecticut Eastern Railroad Museum, founded by members of the Connecticut Eastern Chapter of the National Railway Historical Society, is located on the site of the Columbia Junction Freight Yard, and has a collection that includes locomotives and rolling stock, vintage railroad buildings, and a six-stall roundhouse reconstructed on the original foundation. Visitors can take a guided tour of the museum, train rides are offered, and guests can even operate a replica 1850s-style pump car on a section of rail.

Connecticut.name: Railroad Museum of New England
Connecticut.description: Based in the historic Thomaston station, the Railroad Museum of New England featured in the Leonardo DiCaprio-Kate Winslet film Revolutionary Road, and has run tourist trains since the 1990s. Diesel locomotives take passengers riding in vintage coaches south alongside the Naugatuck River, or north on excursions to Torrington that cross the high rim of Thomaston Dam. Seasonal and holiday events sell out, as do special event trains on which guests enjoy local chocolate and/or bourbon.

Connecticut.name: Sharon Land Trust
Connecticut.description: A hike through bucolic Mary Moore Preserve in Sharon promises sprawling mountain views and dairy cows

Connecticut.name: Putnam
Connecticut.description: "fairy doors" https://www.putnamct.us/sites/putnamct/files/u101/2017_fairy_door_guide.pdf

Connecticut.description: hike to chaugham lookout

Coogan Farm Nature and Heritage Center

Midtown (34th to 59th).description: A miniature rainforest is growing inside of a Midtown Manhattan office building.
