Midtown (34th to 59th).name: 220 E 42nd St
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: Spinning silently in the lobby of an Art Deco masterwork is a massive vintage model of the Earth.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: 420 Lexington Ave
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: Rat sculptures try to infiltrate the Graybar Building in an architectural tribute to New York City's nautical history.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Grand Central Terminal
Midtown (34th to 59th).description:
A dark patch of the ceiling at Grand Central Terminal which was not restored is still stained brown by tobacco.  
Whisper secrets in a busy station only to be heard on the other side of this acoustic arch.
The famous facade of Grand Central Terminal hides a regulation tennis court, and it's not the first one.  home to city's steepest escalator

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Paley Park
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: A small peaceful park and waterfall tucked amid the urban grind of Midtown Manhattan.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: William Lescaze House and Office
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: New York City's first Modernist house. mid-century modern. first Modern resdience in NYC. designed by Lescaze who pioneered modernism in USA

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: 767 3rd Ave
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: A Manhattan office building is home to the world's largest chess board.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: The Norwegian Seamen's Church in New York
Waldorf-Astoria New York
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: cole porter's piano: A famous songsmith's custom piano, dubbed "High Society," is hidden just out of sight in one of New York's finest hotels.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Saint Peter's Church
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: Nevelson Chapel of Tranquility

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Seagram Building
Midtown (34th to 59th).description:
landmarked interior
plaza in front: "A sea of elegant, perfectly proportioned space carved out of a city of chaos" —Peter Marino

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: 500 Park Ave
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: old pepsico building "It never fails to give me chill bumps. It’s way better than the Lever Building down the road. There is not a bit of fat in the building, and its windows are perfectly proportioned. To me, it reflects peak modernism, peak power, peak New York"

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Central Synagogue
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: every other tue, concerts by a master organist

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: St. Bartholomew's Church
Midtown (34th to 59th).description:
early 1900s church with famed organ  National Historic Landmark designed by Bertram Goodhue in 1918. Combining Byzantine and Romanesque styles, the church often surprises visitors who mistake this Episcopal church for a Catholic or Eastern Orthodox parish.

See the impressive triple portal, commissioned by the Vanderbilt family and designed by McKim, Mead & White in 1903, as well as exquisite mosaics and stained glass by Hildreth Meière, and a magnificent 24-foot-wide Sanctus window designed by Reynolds, Francis and Rohnstock in 1943. Other highlights include a page from the Gutenberg Bible, a baptismal font by Bertel Thorvaldsen, and NYC’s largest pipe organ, an Æolian-Skinner with 12,422 pipes.

See how the welcoming and affirming community at St. Bartholomew’s Church brings life to this historic space. Nestled among the city’s high-rises, the church offers a quiet refuge in the heart of Manhattan. View how history, art, and faith come together in this peaceful setting.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Charles Scribner's Sons Building
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: landmarked interior

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Four Seasons Hotel New York
Midtown (34th to 59th).description:
The Four Seasons Hotel New York stands out as the only hotel in the Western Hemisphere designed by I.M. Pei. 
With walls made of the same honey-colored French limestone Mr. Pei used at The Louvre, the 33-foot soaring lobby ceiling of the 52-story hotel resonates with the height of the building’s surrounding skyscrapers. One flight up from the street is the lobby’s rotunda, which is circled by eight pillars that accent a suspended, backlit onyx ceiling.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Lotte New York Palace
Midtown (34th to 59th).description:
The spacious, bi-level marble lobby of the Lotte New York Palace not only evokes grandeur but also harmoniously blends the two elements of this storied 909-room property: the landmark Villard Mansion (on Madison Avenue) and its contemporary 55-story hotel tower.

The Madison Avenue courtyard entrance to the hotel, which once welcomed carriages, leads to the hotel’s grand staircase and lower lobby below. Off the stately foyer are two event spaces, the oval Villard Ballroom and Reid Salon. One especially impressive feature is its restored red Verona marble fireplace, originally designed for the mansion by Augustus Saint-Gaudens. With classic columns, rich woods and warm carpeting, the reception area and private entranceway to The Towers are located in the lower lobby.

Take a peek: Visitors can enjoy cocktails and light snacks under the gilt ceilings of The Gold Room; located within the Villard Mansion; stop in at Troubles Trust, the bar tucked under the grand staircase; enjoy a personalized drinking experience by reservation at Rarities, or enjoy seasonal baked goods and other indulgences at Pomme Palais on the ground floor.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: St. Thomas Church
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: recently restored windows

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Holy Family Roman Catholic Church
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: garden

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Chanin Building
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: art deco building; exterior references Darwins theory of evolution; check out lobby

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Bowery Savings Bank Building
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: landmarked interior

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Private Passage Sculpture
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: Wine bottle sculpture with a ship's stateroom inside.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Pier 96 at Hudson River Park
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: free kayaking

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Avevida 6 1/2
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: Tucked away amidst some of the most famous addresses in the world is New York's only fraction of a street.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Nintendo
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: Though the case is scorched and the buttons half-melted, this hardy handheld gaming device can still run a game of Tetris.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: The Actors' Temple
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: A Hell's Kitchen synagogue that has counted stars of stage and screen among its congregation.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Silver Towers Public Park
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: This sculptural piece by the artist Tom Otterness doubles as a jungle gym.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Spotlight on Broadway
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: The 28-foot granite map plots the locations of 40 theaters in New York City.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: 1552 Broadway
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: Amid the marketing blitz of modern Times Square is an elegant holdover from its showbiz glory days. THESE DAYS, IT’S HARD TO find much of the original heart of old Times Square. But on the corner of Broadway and West 46th Street, above the crowds of tourists and neon signs, is the venerable facade of Israel Miller’s shoe store, looking much as it did a hundred years ago.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Max Neuhaus, “Times Square”
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: A pedestrian island in the middle of world-famous Times Square emits a strange (and purposeful) humming noise.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Beast & Butterflies
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: great rooftop views

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: St. Mary the Virgin's Church
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: This Episcopal church was founded in 1868 for the neighborhood of Longacre Square, now called Times Square. Known for its heavy of use of incense, the church is sometimes called Smoky Mary’s. The main attraction here is the well-preserved Gothic architecture—with vaulting columns ideal for its famous booming organ pipes—along with the splashes of blue and gold added during a ’90s redecoration.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: One Times Square
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: This historic address is home to the beloved ball and is an almost totally empty building among the most expensive real estate in the world.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Times Sq–42 St
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: Fake subway tiles were installed to cover a design that resembled the Confederate flag—it's unclear if the resemblance was intentional.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Bryant Park Public Restroom
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: The fanciest public restroom in New York City boasts fresh flowers, art, and a classical music soundtrack.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Sutton Place Park South
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: famous from Woody Allen's Manhattan; replica of Florence's bronze boar statue

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Rockefeller Guest House by Philip Johnson
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: mid-century modern. one of the first modernist homes in the city. Johnson's only nyc residence

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Modulightor Inc
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: first friday of every month they have wine & cheese receptions

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Lever House
Midtown (34th to 59th).description:
Commercial office design was forever changed with the completion of SOM’s Lever House in 1952 as the first International Style building in the United States. In a city characterized by masonry and brick, the blue-green glass and steel facade reimagined the potential of office buildings and demonstrated that successful office design could prioritize its community. Instead of designating the ground floor for retail, we created a public space. Rather than maximizing rentable floor area, we placed the office floors atop an elevated, horizontal base and set them perpendicular to Park Avenue. This design established a light and airy plaza and introduced a new relationship between the office and public realm.

Since then, the landmark has been under the care of SOM for more than 70 years, a level of stewardship that is rare in the architectural profession. SOM restored its facade in 2001, and returned again in 2023 to complete the building’s restoration for the 21st century. Join Principal Frank Mahan of a tour of the completely updated plaza and outdoor spaces, a lovingly restored lobby, and new mechanical systems that improve energy efficiency; and witness how the project has recaptured this midcentury icon’s original splendor as Park Avenue’s premier boutique office.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: St. Thomas Church
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: recently restored windows

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Laurie M Tisch Foundation
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: The Illumination Fund’s office is an extension of the foundation’s mission and values, with contemporary art, exhibits by our grantees, and furniture that supports community artisans and social enterprises. The space was designed by BKSK Architects to “illuminate” community and social justice issues and to spark creativity.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: The Art Students League of New York
Paramount Building
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: lobby modelled after Paris opera house

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: General Society of Mechanics & Tradesmen of The City of New York
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: Hundreds of antique bank vault locks on display in New York City. Tucked away on the sixth floor of The General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen, the Institute of Classical Architecture & Art’s Cast Hall displays a collection of historical plaster casts of Classical and Renaissance architecture and sculpture (originally owned by the Metropolitan Museum of Art) alongside fragments of historical woodwork from significant buildings and country houses in the UK. The gallery now plays host to scores of visitors, ranging from students to practicing artists. Visit Cast Hall for open sketching and to learn about this historic art practice and collection.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: One Vanderbilt
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: in lobby: Generated by a computer program using data points influenced by the season, sunrise and sunset, “Continuous Life and Death at the Now of Eternity II” (free) is a digital garden of seasonal blossoms such as chrysanthemums, azaleas and hydrangeas. The evolving garden, which never repeats but echoes the real weather conditions outside, is displayed on a roughly 27-by-16-foot public screen in the lobby of 1 Vanderbilt, a skyscraper next door to Grand Central Terminal. The work, which dominates a route frequented by commuters, seems designed to be viewed consistently by the same people across seasons and years.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Chrysler Building
Midtown (34th to 59th).description:
There are no tickets for the Chrysler Building. You may enter the lobby anytime the building is open, which is 8:00 am to 6 pm (18:00) on weekdays.

You can see the beautiful mural on the ceiling, the clock, and the beautiful elevators, each with its own custom-designed doors.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: The Town Hall
Midtown (34th to 59th).description:
Six women suffragists built “The Peoples’ Hall” – a place open to all where people from all walks of life could gather and hear about the issues of the day in an open forum. The acoustically superior auditorium was designed using the most advanced design technology of its day by the nation’s most revered architecture firm. Shortly after its dedication the hall hosted its first concert, kicking off a proud tradition of milestone musical performances by artists ranging from Billie Holiday to Bob Dylan.

The Town Hall also played host to millions of nationwide radio listeners from 1935-1955 on the public affairs program, “America’s Town Meeting of the Air.”

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: American Indian Community House
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: Currently located on the 20th floor of a Midtown office building, the American Indian Community House is the oldest Native American non profit in the Tri-state area. Since its inception in 1969, AICH has provided a launchpad for many artists and cultural producers and provided healthcare and workforce services to thousands upon thousands of people. It continues to serve as a sanctuary for many Native communities in New York City. A gallery of Native American artwork features works from throughout AICH’s history.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: East Midtown Greenway
Midtown (34th to 59th).description:
The East Midtown Greenway is an in-water linear park from East 53rd to East 61st Streets that provides public access to Manhattan’s East River where the FDR highway previously dominated the waterfront. Completed in 2023, the nearly half-mile pedestrian esplanade is built over the water, rising above 2100 sea level rise, and links to the larger esplanade system that encircles Manhattan. The design minimizes visual obstruction by utilizing structural interstitial spaces to conceal substantial soil volumes for a robust planting design and to allow large trees to anchor naturally against wind. Stormwater is captured and flows within the structure to passively irrigate plantings selected to withstand the harsh conditions of the location, including salts, winds, and periodic drought.

The park’s design makes the most of variations in slope, elevation, and orientation between the pedestrian and cycling paths to create different kinds of spaces and take advantage of spectacular views along the narrow length of the park. Project features include overlooks, seating nooks, lush planting, and environmental integrated art from Stacy Levy.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: one of New York’s last remaining Gilded Age treasures. Completed in 1875, the church predates the nearby St. Patrick’s Cathedral (1878) and Plaza Hotel (1907). The stunning ceiling of this Victorian Gothic masterwork rises six stories above the floor. The 1,800-seat Sanctuary contains no iconography (in keeping with early Presbyterian austerity) and no right angles; the curvature of the balcony and pews draws all eyes to the impressive pulpit.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: M & S Schmalberg
Midtown (34th to 59th).description: When Morris and Sam Schmalberg entered the flower business in 1916, the New York City Garment District produced most women’s and children’s fashion apparel in the United States. By the 1940s, dozens of “flower guys” were manufacturing fabric flowers. Today, M&S Schmalberg is the last of its kind in America, surviving as a domestic factory in a world dominated by imported goods. The company has evolved to focus on specialty custom fabric flower projects for couture fashion designers, milliners, and costume designers.

Midtown (34th to 59th).name: PENN 2
Midtown (34th to 59th).description:
The original Pennsylvania Station, designed by McKim, Mead & White, symbolized the lost beauty of rail travel and public space in the United States following its demolition in 1963. The office building that replaced it lacked a connection to the city, didn’t accommodate the public, and was failing to provide for its tenants. MdeAS Architects and Vornado Realty Trust envisioned a new building on the site that embodied the most progressive ideals in the workplace typology today. After many studies, it was determined that preserving the existing structure could actually create the best environment while reducing carbon emissions and costs.

Today, PENN 2 has been transformed with a new high-performance façade, an iconic free-spanning addition called The Bustle, a 288,000-diode LED art installation, 75,000 square feet of new outdoor area, and world class amenities and office space. The tour will go inside The Bustle, onto the terraces, and access exclusive amenities, including the 17,000 sq ft roof park.
